\documentclass[11pt]{article}
\usepackage[a4paper,margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}
\usepackage{hyperref}

\title{A Fit-Free Periodic Table Engine from Eight-Tick Cadence and $\varphi$-Tiers}
\author{Recognition Physics Institute}
\date{\today}

\begin{document}
\maketitle

\begin{abstract}
We present a zero-parameter engine for periodic-table trends based on two
Recognition Science invariants: (i) a forced eight-tick cadence that induces
eight-window neutrality ``rests'' at closures, and (ii) $\varphi$-scaled shell
rails with fixed block offsets (s/p/d/f) by $\varphi$-packing. Using a single
coherence tick $E_{\mathrm{coh}}$, we predict fit-free bands for first/second
ionization energies, electron-affinity sign flips, and covalent/ionic radii
breaks. We publish explicit falsifiers and dataset pins.
\end{abstract}

\section{Engine}
Shell rails: $E_n = E_{\mathrm{coh}}\,\varphi^{2n}$. Fixed block offsets
(s,p,d,f) enter as integer powers of $\varphi$. Eight-window neutrality is
tested by a sliding sum of a fit-free valence-cost proxy across aligned blocks
of eight atoms; noble gases minimize the windowed sum.

\paragraph{Fit-free proxy and normalization.}
Let $B(Z)$ be the predicted block multiplier at atomic number $Z$, and let
$\mathrm{IE1}(Z)$ denote the first ionization energy (dataset pin: NIST IE).
We compare $\mathrm{IE1}(Z)/E_{\mathrm{coh}}$ to $B(Z)$, forming residuals
$r(Z)=\mathrm{IE1}(Z)/E_{\mathrm{coh}}-B(Z)$ without any fitting. Eight-window
neutrality uses $\sum_{k=0}^7 r(Z+k)$ over aligned windows.

\section{Outputs and falsifiers}
Outputs: IE1/IE2 band envelopes, EA sign flips, radii kinks. Falsifiers:
(i) residuals do not cluster on $\varphi^{2n}$ rails; (ii) no local minima for
sliding eight-window sums at noble gases.

\section{CLI and Reproducibility}
We provide a single-command scaffold that emits $\varphi$-tier tables, per-$Z$
predictions, and neutrality scores against optional IE/EA/radii CSVs:
\begin{verbatim}
python scripts/chem/periodic_table_engine.py --Zmax 118 \
  --ie_csv data/IE1.csv --ie2_csv data/IE2.csv --ea_csv data/EA.csv \
  --radii_csv data/R.csv --tol 1e-2 --out results/chem/
\end{verbatim}
Dataset pins are recorded under \texttt{@DATASETS} in \texttt{Source.txt}.

\section{Reproducibility}
We pin NIST IE/EA tables and standard radii compilations; a containerized
script rebuilds all figures from a single command.

\end{document}
